hostNotes.text: Welcome. I am X and today we will explore events and systemic strcutures for others for around 15 minutes. We’ll be doing an audio exercise, followed by time for reflection and finally sharing with each other – if we're up for it.

Let’s start with a mini check-in. How are you feeling right now? Please answer in two-three words. X, would you like to start? > Let everyone in the session, including yourself, check in one by one. Thank you all for checking in. Let’s get started.

Find a comfortable position. I will start the audio exercise and we'll meet back here afterwards. 

> Push play to start the audio exercise

Now we’ll take 1 minutes to reflect on our own. How was that experience for you? “How might analyzing events and behaviors in this way help us empathize with others? How might it help us practice self-compassion towards ourselves?

You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own. 1 minute starting now.

> Press play to start the timer.

That’s 1 minute and it’s time to move on.

Now we are getting into the sharing part. We have three rules for sharing:

1. **What is said in here, stays in here.**
2. **All you need to do is listen.** There is no fixing, helping or advice-giving needed. We are just showing up and exploring what ourselves and others are going through.

3. **Everything on the inside is okay.** Anger, love, hatred, sadness. Whatever shows up. No wrongs, no rights. It is what it is.

There will be a timer set for 2 minutes as an indicator. If you don’t want to share you can always say ‘pass’.

Who would like to start?

> Let everyone (or as many as you got time for) share one by one. Press play to start the timer. Re-start for each new sharing.

Thank you so much everyone.

content.text: How might analyzing events and behaviors in this way help us empathize with others? • How might it help us practice self-compassion towards ourselves?
When we look at these factors we start to see how that behavior is taking place within a broader system of interdependence.”

hostNotes.text: Well done. Today, we’ve explored systems thinking by using the metaphor of an iceberg.
This has helped us to more deeply understand an action or event by considering the many  variables and factors that have led to it, including underlying systemic structures.

Rather than placing all blame or praise on an individual, we can identify how internal and external structures, some of which are beyond an individual’s control, contribute to events. This understanding can deepen an appreciation of interdependence and common humanity

Who would like to start? > Let everyone in the session check out one by one. Thank you all for checking out and for joining this session today. > Finish session to send everyone off to the exit experience.

content.text:
If you’re up for it, you can continue with this mission.

Reflect on a situation where you had a difficult encounter with a thought or another person. How could using the model of iceberg help to encourage compassion for yourself and others in that thought of situation.
content.heading: Well done

en.name: Iceberg

hostNotes.text:
> Press play to start the audio exercise
>
>
>
>

en.description: We are going to explore a deeper way of looking at events, by analyzing how they rest upon systemic structures. Often an action (such as someone being rude or failing a test) is not understood within a larger context; rather, it is merely ascribed to a perceived pattern of behavior (being rude in general or not studying enough). Using the image of an iceberg, students are taught  to go deeper in their analysis. Lets learn to look for deeper systemic structures—both internal and  external—that reinforce the patterns of behaviors that contribute to individual events. Addressing  these deeper systemic structures can help us to  understand events and patterns of behavior  better, and provide insights that help us to take more effective action in changing such patterns
